channel.title: NYT > Business > Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump Has a New Auto Loan Tax Break. Here’s Who Could Benefit.
item.description: Many Americans can take advantage of President Trump’s deduction on auto loan interest, but the tax break will provide only modest savings.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella

item.title: Trump Administration Downplays A.I. Risks, Ignoring Economists’ Concerns
item.description: The administration has downplayed concerns — from mass job losses, to a potential financial bubble — as President Trump cheers soaring stock prices and faster growth.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Colby Smith

item.title: U.S. Coast Guard Pursues Oil Tanker Linked to Venezuela
item.description: The latest vessel to be targeted by the United States in its pressure campaign on Venezuela was sending distress signals as it headed northeast from the Caribbean into the Atlantic.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas, Christiaan Triebert, Tyler Pager, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Eric Schmitt

item.title: Why Middle-Class Americans Say Life Is Unaffordable
item.description: Economists say that a typical middle-class family today is richer than one in the 1960s. Americans in their 20s and 30s don’t believe it.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise

item.title: ‘A Singularly Turbulent Time’: Deeper Uncertainty in Store for Global Economy
item.description: A reordering of the rules of trade, set on top of transformational change in technology, demographics and climate, is remaking jobs, politics and lives.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen

item.title: U.S. Inflation Slowed to 2.7% in November as Shutdown Distorts Data
item.description: Data collection issues skewed the latest Consumer Price Index report, economists warned, clouding the picture for the Federal Reserve as it also grapples with a cooling labor market.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

item.title: Trump Dangles Cash Payments to Assuage Affordability Concerns
item.description: With tariffs unpopular and prices still high, the White House has teased the promise of tariff rebates and large tax refunds next year.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Andrew Duehren

item.title: U.S. Threatens Penalties Against European Tech Firms Amid Regulatory Fight
item.description: The Trump administration singled out European tech firms by name and promised economic consequences Tuesday unless the E.U. rolls back tech regulation and lawsuits.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson, Adam Satariano and Jeanna Smialek

item.title: White House Dismisses Rise in Unemployment
item.description: The Trump administration looked to recast elements of a dour jobs report Tuesday as a sign of strength.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm

item.title: Jobs Report Could Provide Overdue Clarity on Uncertain Economy
item.description: Employers added 64,000 jobs in November, according to data delayed by the government shutdown, but the unemployment rate rose to a four-year high of 4.6 percent.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Davis O’Brien

item.title: Europe May Roll Back Combustion Engine Ban
item.description: A proposal to revise an E.U. law requiring carmakers to stop producing combustion engines by 2035 would offer some relief to automakers, but it sets back the region’s climate goals.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen and Eshe Nelson

item.title: Trump’s Nvidia Chip Deal Reverses Decades of Technology Restrictions
item.description: President Trump’s decision to allow Nvidia to sell its chips to China has raised questions about whether he is prioritizing short-term economic gain over long-term American security interests.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger

item.title: U.S.-U.K. Trade Deal Hits Stumbling Block
item.description: The U.S. government has paused a tech-focused trade pledge with Britain over broader disagreements about Britain’s digital regulations and food safety rules.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson and Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump’s $100,000 H-1B Fee Faces Lawsuit
item.description: California and New York are among the states arguing that the Trump administration’s decision to charge that fee for skilled foreign workers is illegal.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado

item.title: Businesses Are Cashing In on Trump’s Tax Cuts
item.description: Corporate tax revenue has quickly dipped since Republicans passed tax cuts this summer. But economists think these tax breaks might be worth it.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Duehren

item.title: Cooling Labor Market and Elevated Inflation Stoke Fed Divisions on Rate Cuts
item.description: Fed officials explained their opposition to the central bank’s decision this week to cut interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

item.title: Trump’s Tariffs Shrank the U.S. Trade Deficit in September
item.description: The monthly trade deficit fell to its lowest level in five years after the president’s imposition of sweeping global tariffs. But it’s unclear whether the trend will persist.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump Doesn’t Want to Talk About Affordability. Democrats Say That’s a Gift.
item.description: The president continues to brush off an issue that he said he would solve in his first months in office. Some Democrats say he is making the same mistake as his predecessor.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green

item.title: The Fed Cut Rates Again but Deep Divisions Cloud Path Ahead
item.description: The central bank’s decision to lower interest rates for a third straight meeting was highly contentious, reflecting an internal divide that will likely limit how much borrowing costs will fall next year.
item.dc:creator: Colby Smith

item.title: Why the A.I. Boom Is Unlike the Dot-Com Boom
item.description: Silicon Valley is again betting everything on a new technology. But the mania is not a reboot of the late-1990s frenzy.
item.dc:creator: David Streitfeld
